To please our rough illiterate Sires</br>Rude minstrels tun'd their native lyres;</br>Tho' stern the temper of the times,</br>They felt the power of homely rhimes;</br>Tho' sever'd by the surly main,</br>Sweet Poesy here rais'd her strain.</br>Our home-inspir'd Bards of old</br>Amus'd our Knights and Barons bold;</br>So could pathetic ballads move</br>To arms, to pity, or to love.</br>No fabled streams, nor Grecian glades</br>They knew, nor Heliconian maids;</br>Yet Nature taught them glorious themes,</br>They sung of woods and azure streams,</br>In war what dangers Heroes prove,</br>And what the woes of faithful Love.</br>Alfred by song his Saxons train'd,</br>And savage manners were restrain'd;</br>By song did Chaucer, antient Sage,</br>Instruct his rough, heroic age.

But when at length bright Learning's day</br>Had chac'd the morning clouds away,</br>True Taste illumin'd all the isle,</br>And classic Genius deign'd to smile:</br>The destin'd aera now was come,</br>When we should rival Greece and Rome.</br>Harmonious Spenser, at the head,</br>Through fairy wilds the Muses led.</br>Then Shakespear rose, of boundless mind,</br>And held a mirror to mankind.</br>Milton, divine enthusiast, shone</br>In themes to antient Bards unknown:</br>He on aspiring pinions soar'd,</br>And Heaven's glorious realms explor'd;</br>He view'd the Earth in all its show,</br>And rang'd the awful worlds below:</br>While utter darkness veil'd his eyes,</br>Each night a Spirit from the skies</br>With hymns consol'd his lonely hours,</br>Befriended by the harmonious powers.</br>Then Dryden charm'd the wondering times,</br>Nor felt the shackles of his rhimes;</br>His breast with native spirit glow'd,</br>From him the verse instinctive flow'd,</br>And to this Poet England owes</br>The chastest graces of her prose:</br>Penury and Superstition blind</br>Could not depress his vigorous mind;</br>But yet the morals of his age</br>Too often stain his glowing page.</br>Our favourite Pope, with nicer care,</br>The powers propitious deigned to rear:</br>Sound learning, thought and taste refin'd,</br>To form his genius were combin'd,</br>And Virtue tip'd his arrows keen,</br>Tho' wounded knaves might term it spleen.</br>Nor here can I forget that Northern Bard,</br>Whose honest fame has far been heard;</br>Thomson, whose manly, natural lays,</br>Amus'd my early, sauntering days.</br>O wanderer of Richmond's Vale,</br>Thy generous spirit let me hail!</br>The Doric melody, the Muse</br>Did not to thy grave songs refuse;</br>Fond Fancy o'er they visions smil'd,</br>And Nature show'd her beauties wild!</br>But long the task to tell each name</br>Mark'd in the kalendar of Fame;</br>Nor ought we thankless to disdain</br>Whate'er the Muse, of chaster vein,</br>Has in our later age inspir'd;</br>Our Druid Mason is admir'd,</br>And more his nobler brother Gray;</br>Nor scorn we Beattie's minstrel lay.

But, ah, the change!  nor pastoral strains</br>From green-corn pipe the British Swains</br>Delight; nor dares the sounding lyre</br>With Freedom's airs the mind inspire.</br>Why sleeps the spirit of the song?</br>Why mute the Poet's sacred tongue?</br>Does Fate to stated times restrain</br>Poetic Inspiration's reign?</br>Does coming Slavery damp the mind,</br>Or Luxury debase mankind?</br>I fear our weak, unmanly rhimes</br>Too well bespeak degenerate times.</br>Where shall some happy Genius rise,</br>On whom the Chauntress of the Skies</br>Serene with natal omens smil'd?</br>If such there be, O hide the child</br>From envious eyes and blasting air;</br>Remove him far from vulgar care;</br>And let not Penury forlorn,</br>Or Sorrow chill his opening morn:</br>Ye Powers that love the Poet's strain,</br>Avert th' ungenerous Slaves of Gain!</br>Those monsters vile corrupt the soul,</br>And think that Genius is a Fool.</br>But let our Youth sweet converse hold</br>With spirits generous and bold,</br>Who love each ever-glowing page</br>Of Homer, and the Mantuan Sage.</br>Those wonders let him oft survey,</br>Which Nature's ample scenes display:</br>Along the promontory's brow,</br>While Ocean foams and roars below,</br>Let him each awful rock explore,</br>When tempests wrap their summits hoar:</br>But never, never may he miss</br>Those hours of chaste, extatic bliss,</br>When all the purpled welkin streams</br>With blushing morn or evening's beams;</br>Or, o'er the oaks and hillocks green,</br>The full-orb'd Moon is rising seen:</br>In tranquil vallies let him rove,</br>And hear the carol of the grove,</br>Where whispering leaves, of various green,</br>And brawling brooks, divert the scene.</br>Mid rural innocence and truth,</br>With spotless Nymph, or artless Youth,</br>His Summer-hours let him enjoy,</br>Estrang'd to all unhallow'd joy:</br>Let generous love of human kind,</br>And hopes of fame, exalt his mind.</br>If such there be, he yet our praise</br>May gain, and claim the antient bays;</br>He yet new fountains may explore,</br>And regions never trod before.</br>Should such a prodigy arise,</br>And tempt with eagle's wings the skies,</br>O grant that I may hear his lay,</br>Before I join my kindred clay!</br>Let glowing Pleasure rule my heart,</br>Subdu'd by his victorious art;</br>While he shall in inspired verse</br>Heroic thoughts and deeds rehearse.</br>Disdaining plain historic life,</br>Each mean event and trivial strife,</br>Such high ideas he will find</br>As reach the grandeur of the mind.</br>
